SP.P: Yes he has talked too much—he will repent his talking ere long. But come Alice, this is no time for talking with me—I must give thee a kiss for com∣fort, and then to the battle.

LG.L: Inur'd to wars and rude alarms,
Unshaken amid the din of arms,
We startle not at Terror's dismal yells:
The shouts and clangors of the foe,
The horrors Death and Danger know,
But animate the heart where Courage dwells.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Heaven be with thee, Adam—I love thee, and in spite of all my mother can say against thee, ever shall love thee.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: How can my mother chide my love?
How can she frown and scold me?
How can she say he'll faithless prove,
As she has often told me!

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Ah! did she know his winning wiles!
Ah! could she taste such blisses!
And heard his oaths, and saw his smiles,
And felt his precious kisses!
She would not surely chide my love,
She would not frown and scold me;
She would not say he'll faithless prove,
As she has often told me.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: His lips are like the sugar-pea,
His tongue is dipt in honey;
His words are dearer far to me
Than waggon loads of money!
Then do not, mother, chide my love,
Then do not frown and scold me;
Then do not say he'll faithless prove,
As you have often told me.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Prithee, Fool, good Fool, afford me conso∣lation—give me comfort, most sage Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: I can't—cannot—unless I could give you wings—There is no escaping—bolts and bars forbid—stone walls are not to be moved with fine speeches—Rhe∣toric is lost—eloquence thrown away upon 'em—a key is your only Counsellor in this case.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Is it not very strange, Fool, that I should be as valiant as Alexander at some moments, and at others have no propensity to molest even a mouse? No man in England is at this instant less inclined to mis∣chief, murder, and bloodshed, than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: Then you have no inclination to die like a Hero, that you may live for ever?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Not the least in the world as I hope for mercy—my thoughts are all turned to tranquillity—Peace—peace and quietness is my wish—and, when one considers, that—that now is really a most virtuous disposition—Why should I cut any man's throat? Or why should any man cut mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: How will Anlaff understand that logic▪ when he finds that you are the person who kill'd his brother Alric?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I didn't, Fool, I didn't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: No—Thank heaven I have not that sin to answer for—I kill'd nobody—"Nay more"—I never kill'd a man in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: Never kill'd a man in your life!

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: Zounds, what a shame that is!

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg
SP.P: And I shall think it exceedingly hard if any body kills me. Oh Lord! What is that!
SP.STAGE: [Shouts, and founding of the bugle born is heard.
SP.P:
Yes, yes, it is the Danes—What shall I do? I tremble all over—shale like a cobweb in a high wind—my imagination is haunted by ten thousand furious figures of bloody-minded Danes▪ I shall certainly be murder∣ed
if I don't keep out of the way, [looks] Hark! [Noise again and born] They are entered! [Noise] Aye, aye, they are at it—I'll hide myself in this corner till their first fury is abated [Gets beneath the armour] Oh that I could go to sleep!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Where can this vaunting coward▪ this ignomi∣nious Earl have hid himself?—Hark you, sirrah, do you know any thing of! all Egbert?

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: I know Earl Egbert, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Do you know any thing of him, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, many things—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I perceive by your countenance and equivoca∣tion you know where he is, and if you won't tell me peaceably, I will take you by the heels, and shake the secret out of you, sirrah.
SP.STAGE: [Leonard lays hold of the Fool, who imme∣diately points to the place where E. Egbert is concealed]

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: Sir—if you were to shake my soul out of me, I would not say a word.—Nay—kill me if you please—separate me like an opened oyster, but I won't speak.
SP.STAGE: [The Fool keeps pointing till Leonard goes and overturns the armour, and discovers Earl Egbert.]

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Be gone, sirrah. [Exit Fool.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV3.P: Thou shameless Lord! thou disgrace to honour—But I have no Time to waste with a Thing so bale and insignificant.—Rise—listen and obey.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I will, good Sir, I will—what would you please to have me do?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Anlaff, the Dane, has sent a Herald with a challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Oh Lord! a challenge! To whom, pray'

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
To the man who vanquished his brother Al the conditions , Anlaff will give hostags that i he
be conquered, the Danes immediately shall quit the castle; but if he conquer, the life of his enemy shall remain in his power, and Edwitha be given for his Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Lord Sir! what's all this to me? You know I never killed Alric his brother, and you or he are very welcome to the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Hear me, wretch!

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Go to Earl Walter—and with your yesterday's confidence profess yourself the Vanquisher of Alric, and the Foe of Anlaff—Then send your own armour hither by your Dwarf, together with the sword and shield you so valiantly took from the dead Alric; and after that, go hide—hang yourself—only be sure to keep out of sight.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: That, Sir, at least you may depend upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Away then—You are safe, therefore swell, and look important.—Dare not to fail—observe me—on your life dare not to fail.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I will endeavour, Sir, to obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: This Reptile almost makes me forget, respect, and assume a chacter I detest.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: What are you determined, Leonard, to fight the Dane?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: But wherefore do you take the disguise of that cowardly Earl?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Why ask you that?—you know it is a conditi∣on in the challenge of the haughty Anlaff, that he will not debase himself to fight any whose birth and origin are obscure or mean.—"Besides—I—but 'tis no matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P:
Well Leonard, there is not an arm on earth I would more gladly commit the protection of every
thing most dear to, than to thine.—And yet—I am not without fear—The Dane is a bold, and almost matchless Warriour—Never yer equalled by his most renowned or desperate Foe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: "Aye!"—But I have a cause would nerve an Infant!—Edwitha! Love! and Edwitha!

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Love and Edwitha! you rave, Leonard—And yet impossible as it is that love like this should be successful, I almost rejoice at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Aye, 'tis a noble passion, that adds strength and dignity to courage, gives magnanimity to the lover's enthusiasm, and makes the young Hero more than mor∣tal.—But we talk too long—Have you informed and cautioned our companions?

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: I have—their hearts and prayers are with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Away then, good Adam, watch the behaviour of that foolish Earl, and confirm him, if you should perceive him faultering.—Hole—take this Letter, and find some private way of conveying is to Edwitha, be∣fore we enter the lists.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Well, Leonard—e firm—be resolute—be—yourself—Farewell.—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Farewell!—I go, determined, to a glorious Victory!—or a glorious Fa!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Clym o' the Clough, and Will. Cloudeslee.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Welcome, my friends, every thing conspires to procure our pardon. We have only to sight brave∣ly, and ply our bows as formerly, and we shall become sons of grace and favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Clym.
SP.P: Why look you, Adam, you know me—I am no Flincher—I conquer, or—or there's an end of me—that's all

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: And a dead man, Clym, don't value an angry King.

SP.SPEAKER: Clym.
SP.P: Right, lad.—He that fights and wins, may sup in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: And he that fights and dies, don't want any supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: We shall have warm work.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: It's not the first time I have been in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Clym.
SP.P: He that never was in danger, never knew the sweets of safety.

LG.L: When, o'er the World, the playful Lamb
Hath, till the dusky twilight, stray'd,
His tender plaints cry Here I am
Of night and solitude afraid.
But if, far off, his Dam he hears,
Echoing oft the mournful bleat,
He runs, and stops, and hopes, and sears,
And bounds with pleasure when they meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: Well, my lads, since reformation's the word, why I 'll reform; we have spent many a merry day together, but if they pardon an treat us like men, why so—if not—

SP.SPEAKER: Clym.
SP.P: If not, Will, I am an outlaw again.

SP.SPEAKER: Will.
SP.P: And I▪ by this right hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: And I—But sear it not—they are noble, and we are brave.

DIV1.HEAD: ANCIENT GLEE, composed in the year 1500.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: We three Archers be,
Rangers that rove through the North Country,
Lovers of ven'fon and liberty,
That value not honours or money.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: We three good follows be,
That never yet ran from three times three,
Quarter-staff, broad-sword, or bow-manry,
But give us fair play for our money.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: We three merry men be,
At a lass or a glass under green wood tree;
Jocundly chaunting our auncient Glee,
Though we have not a penny of money.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII. Changes to the Court-yard of the Castle.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Earl Walter, Earl Egbert, Dwarf, Saxon He∣rald, Edwitha, Adela, and Adam Bell.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: You have heard, brave Egbert, the chal∣lenge of the imperious Anlaff, and the threat of instant saccage, if refused. You see the almost impossibility of our making a stand against his multitudes, and you know the personal prowess of the Dane. Put there∣fore all consideration of the particular safety of me or mine aside.—Consult your own feelings, and let them alone direct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Heavens! How I tremble.—He surely will not dare to accept the challenge.— [Aside to Adela.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Will he drink boiling Lead dost think? or stand a tiptoe on a church Steeple?

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: You know your lesson; speak confidently.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: My Lord—hem—I—Are you sure the youth dare fight this Anlast? [Aside to Adam Bell.]

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Yes—And I am sure the youth dare cut your throat if you don't leave your quaking▪ and speak in your other voice.—Come Sir,—mouth a little.—Ut∣ter your big breath. [Aside to Egbert.]

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg
SP.P: Hem! My Lord—hem—deeds done in open day—must see the light.—That I have done the deed which doth stir the gall of the angry Dane is notorious and past recall.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Dost hear Adela? He is going to pronounce my condemnation. [Aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Pooh—silly—dost thou not know him? 'Tis all flourish.—One bright blaze, and the snuff is out.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Alric is dead.—Swelling renown sits perched upon my Crest.—Anlaff would pluck it thence and transplant it to his own.—Anlaff—is mighty in strength—in bone—in ligament and sinew awful!—I am—but as other men.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Ay—Think of that, good Earl Egbert, re∣member that.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I—I do—I do.—Were I to compare my∣self to the Dane,—my wrist to his,—my leg,—or estimate success, by breadth of back—

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: And how else, would you estimate my Lord? you have no charm, to make yourself invulnerable.—Blows—wounds,—and death—must determine the fearful Conflict—If you once pronounce the dreadful yes, fight you must—there is no retreating—and die you must, unless you conquer.—Anlaff will never forgive his brother's death.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Thanks dear girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Fear nothing—observe his lip; that pro∣claims his thought.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Why—these—these—a—'tis true—are circumstances, that will obtrude upon the fancy in Valor's spight—and therefore—it will argue pru∣dence in me to decline the combat. [During the next side speeches, Earl Walter seems engaged in speaking to the Herald, and Adela and Edwitha with each other.]

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: S'death! what do you mean? accept the challenge instantly—Shake off your fears, and ap∣pear confirmed, or by heaven I 'll stab you—What sheep you are not to fight. [Aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: I had forgot—I will, I will [Aside.]—I say My Lord.—Or I meant to say,—These circumstances weighed might induce, a—a cautious man to turn recreant, and decline the desperate contest—but no—

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: I am lost.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: No, no, no!—I am fixed—immoveable—determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Well said, Sir—proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Eg.
SP.P: Away Herald, and hurl defiance forth.—Tell the mighty Anlaff, that Egbert the Va∣liant, who slew Alric the Cruel, will meet him in∣stantly. [Exit Herald, Earl Egbert, and Adam Bell.]

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Why then the die is cast,—and I am the de∣voted victim.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Patience! Is it possible! It cannot be that he dare meet Anlaff! "the Daemon of temerity possesses him"—My Lord you will be shamed, disgraced for ever—my cousin ruined—

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: You are mistaken, Niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: No, Uncle—'Tis you are mistaken—That braggart, that bubble will burst, and leave an ever∣lasting stain upon your house, your happiness, and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: I confess I have my doubts: I did not like his behaviour, and desperate as our condition is, I even hoped he would refuse, but I could not honour∣ably controul his choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: My Lord, your son young Harold, and all his Knights, are hastening to your relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: My brother! Is he arrived?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Half an hour will bring him to the lists.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Happy tidings! Delay the fatal trial my Lord, and save my Edwitha!

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: Oh! that I had the power—But—it must not be—my honour is pledged—the combat must pro∣ceed—Would he had arrived but one short hour sooner!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Why this is madness!—My poor Edwitha!—surely men have conspired thy destruction!—This Coward! this Thing! this Egbert!—But it cannot be!—What, a fellow that faints if he cuts his thumb—that is trembling at an old woman's tale of a ghost—that dare not sleep in the dark—and that would run away from a coat and a hat hung upon a broom-stick to scare crows! He fight An∣laff! he!—Why didst not see how he shook!

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: It is ied most unaccountable. The fear of reproach may, perhaps, for a moment have over∣come his other fears: Be it as it will, there is now no hope for me, and I have only to prepare, and meet my fate becomingly.

LG.L: The rill that from the steep ascent
The mountain pebble washes white,
Mournfully murmuring, as 'tis bent
In search of rest, with anxious flight:
That rill, e'er to the ocean borne,
Shall sooner from its motion cease,
Than my poor heart shall cease to mourn,
Than my poor heart regain its peace.

SP.P: I apprehend the worst, and go with a mind calmly fortified, and a patient resignation to my fate

DIV3.STAGE: An arrow drops at the feet of Edwitha with a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: What is this, Adela? An arrow and a letter? [reads.]
SP.Q: To the fairest of Earthly beauties the Lady Edwitha.
SP.P:
Gentle Saint, Let your holy wishes and fervent prayers be offered to the giver of victories, for—Leonard the Peasant!— [Edwitha looks up at
Adela almost overpowered, but with great expression—reads again] Who is soon to be engaged in all the hazard os mortal strife, for the most virtuous, worthy, and accomplished lady of the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: [After a long sigh] Oh my poor heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: [With her eyes fixed] Why what is this! What aenigma!

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: A Miracle! A Man! A Hero! A Demi∣god! Had heaven granted me a Wish, this should have been the first! That he may be victorious is the second. [With great fervour.]

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Oh, Adela! But now I was acquiescent in the worst of fortunes; had forbad my heart to flut∣ter, reasoned irregularity from my beating pulse, and soothed my troubled passions into apathy—And now—in an instant, with increasing violence, they are all returned, and overwhelm me with a rushing tide of fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Fears! Hopes! Extacies! Unexpected Rap∣tures!—Why girl, thou art as one suddenly cast from a precipice, whom a protecting Angel hath caught falling, and winged to Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Why look thee, Adela—behold the good proportion, the big stature and haughty confidence of the Dane.—Is he not an enemy to be feared?

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: He may be matched.— [Trumpet again.] Yonder is one coming, will teach him humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Nay, but is not that Earl Egbert's armour, Adela?

SP.SPEAKER: Ade
SP.P: Yes, the case is his— [Leonard enters, the Ladies are on the farther side from his entrance]—but observe the step—the gesture, and the form—look at the modest manly air with which it moves; then tell me, though it be the Shell of Egbert, is it animated by the Soul of Egbert, think'st thou?
SP.STAGE: [Leonard bows with a modest respect as he passes, then turns with an attitude of hope and admiration, and goes off to the combat.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: Oh brave, brave youth!

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: The smiles of Heaven, and the strength of Lions go with him!

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: When Scorching Suns the thirsty Earth
Of all her treasures drain,
The Rose, of Summer's loveliest birth,
Droops on the languid plain.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: But when refreshing rains descend
Again the Verdure shoots;
Again reviving Nature sends
Her gifts of flowers and fruits.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: The heart exhausted thus, depress'd,
A prey to ardent Woe,
Revives and smiles, when Joys so blest
Once more unhoped for flow.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XII. Changes to the Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: So, Dwarf, I would advise you to pack—I would counsel you to be gone—you and your thrice valorous Lord—steal off—now, while the hubbub of Contention shall cover your retreat—or you will both die by the dishonourable distaff—Be advised, I say, and run—scud—scamper—skulk.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwa.
SP.P: Think you my honourable Lord will take a Fool's advice?

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: No—he never takes your's—But go—tread, trainple, traverse, trot, travel, trundel, trip, troop, trudge, I say, with trepidation. [Exit Dwarf.

SP.SPEAKER: Fool.
SP.P: The combat is going to begin, and we shall have hopes and fears, and aching hearts, and streaming eyes, and ahs! and ohs! and hurra's! in plenty—It's a great happiness I am a Fool, otherwise these things would make me melancholy—But singing and joking is a merry trade, and I should be a Fool, indeed, to forego the best perquisite of my place—No—let them them fight that will—I'll look on.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: For were a man melancholy
At proofs of others folly,
His days would be wasted wholly
In moaning out oh, oh:
His cares each moment heaping,
His nights all spent in weeping,
He'd want time to eat or to sleep in,
For his tears should eternally flow.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Then let 'em fight and quarrel
For Wealth, or Wench, or Laurel,
Pretending they abhor ill,
Yet I'll laugh out ah, ah!
He that wears the longest rapier
Let him make his enemy caper,
And his soul fiz forth like a vapour,
My trade shall be still ha, ha!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIII. and last.
DIV3.STAGE: The Lists, Danish Knights, &c. arranged on one side, and Archers on the other. Earl Walter, Edwitha and Adela seated on a kind of throne, as near the front as may be. Leonard and Anlaff armed with sword and target. Two Heralds, one Saxon, the other Danish. Trumpeters.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal
SP.P:
Mighty Anlaff, let me demand on the part
of your antagonist, what is your cause of quarrel, and the motive of your present challenge?

SP.SPEAKER: Anl.
SP.P: Revenge for a dear brother, basely slain, and reparation for a rude denial to an honourable proposi∣tion.—Briefly, I seek to win Edwitha, whom I vehe∣mently love, and punish Earl Egbert, whom I as dead∣ly hate.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I demand to know the challenger's source of enmity to Earl Egbert.
SP.STAGE: [Earl Walter is surprized to hear it is not Earl Egbert who speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: Anl.
SP.P: Insolent Lord, I have said—thy proclaimed death of Alric.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then is thy enmity misplaced—For not Earl Egbert, [lifts up his beaver] but I, Leoline, the Bri∣ton, slew thy brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Anl.
SP.P: Leoline! [amazed.] Prince of the Britons!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: In defence of that most chaste and beauteous Lady, I slew him; and again, in her defence, here do I stand in thy defiance, proud Dane; nay further do proclaim my Love for her with a tongue as loud as thine, but with a heart, I hope, less arrogant.—Now, if thou hast a soul worthy of such most matchless Ex∣cellence, let it rouse up every latent faculty, and fill thee with the divine furor of courageous Love.—Behold—look upon that lovely, that inestimable Prize, and be thou equal to a contention so exalted—Come—
SP.STAGE: [The trumpets sound the charge.—The combat:—during which, Edwitha and Adela are greatly agitated. Several turns in which the Cambatants are each in danger, at last Leoline falls on his knee, Anlaff runs furiously at him, he springs on one side, averts the blow, and suddenly disarms the Dane. Shout.]

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: There, Sir, are your arms.—Agreeably to your own condition, your life is in my power—but I do not thirst for blood.—To repel lawless force, and redress the Injured, is the extent of my ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: Astonishment, noble youth, and joy almost deny my tongue the utterance of my full heart's gra∣tude—speak—speak—Edwitha.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: I cannot, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Beauteous Edwitha, why I have appeared in a shape and character so ambiguous shall be the questi∣on, I hope, of many a happy hour.—It was indeed to gain your true affection—not as a Prince, who could confer, but as a Suppliant who besought your favour,—and such let me ever continue.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Why am I silent?—Oh my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I could not come, my Lord, proud of my birth, and heralding, my titles, to claim a jewel so inestima∣ble, so much above the price of Kings, or Kingdoms.—No, Edwitha, though I love you to distraction, could I not first have won your heart, I never would have asked your hand.—My fixed passion, would have descended with me to the grave, but never should have troubled your repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ade.
SP.P: You tell us, my Lord, how much you are in love, but not how you became so.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The fame of Edwitha's beauties, her virtues, and the rare endowments of her mind, of these I had often heard. At last a Knight, who had met courteous entertainment, from my Lord her father here, described her wit, her gentleness, and charms, with such enraptured words, I could no longer re∣sist the secret wish to behold her, which from the moment when first I heard her praise, I had ever cherished.—That my love has been successful, is the happiness and glory of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Do not, generous youth, thus over-rate what you so kindly think valuable, left hereafter you should find me far—far less deserving, and I should lose your Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No, Edwitha—you have a native dignity of mind incapable of degradation or alloy.

SP.SPEAKER: Edw.
SP.P: Well, my Lord, I will at least endeavour to be what you kindly think I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My honour'd Lord, and Father, as I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Wal.
SP.P: Willingly, my Lord—you have given me life and honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Adam, and my brave Associates, now no longer Outlaws, you shall be my Soldiers, and become true men as well as valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Om Ar.
SP.P: Thanks noble Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.P: Sir, we will ever love and serve you faithful∣ly—Alice, Thou art a true-hearted Lass, and shalt listen at night to the tale of thy bonny Adam Bell.

SP.SPEAKER: Alice.
SP.P: Then I shall be the happiest Lass in England.

LG.L: Come, come with songs of mirth and joy,
Let's celebrate the day;
Sing sweetly to the am'rous boy
A dulcet Roundelay.
And you who hope such bliss to prove
Our moral make your care,
Nor till your hearts are worthy love
For love's Delights prepare.
